alert.note: Alert for Los Angeles; Ventura (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued December 22 at 12:55AM PST by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 345 AM PST EARLY THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by heavy rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of southwest California, including southern and Central Los Angeles County and southeastern Ventura County. * WHEN...Until 345 AM PST. * IMPACTS...Flooding of low-lying and poor drainage areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1241 AM PST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated that an area of moderate to heavy rain and isolated thunderstorms have moved into southern Los Angeles County. This area will continue to shift a bit more to the north and west, pushing into central Los Angeles County and southeastern Ventura County. Rainfall rates of 0.20 to 0.40 inches per hour are expected through the early morning hours, with local rates up to 0.75 inches per hour at times and near any thunderstorms. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have already fallen in much of this area, with local totals over 4 inches, and ponding of water on roadways and flooding of low lying areas has been reported. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in widespread ponding of water on area roadways and flooding of low lying areas and intersections. There may be rises and flooding of some creeks and streams. Rocks and boulders may fall onto roadways, especially below steep terrain. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Long Beach, Thousand Oaks, Malibu, Acton, Burbank, Pasadena, Glendale, Torrance, Universal City, North Hollywood, Hollywood, Beverly Hills, Van Nuys, Downtown Los Angeles, Encino, Culver City, Santa Monica, Woodland Hills and Northridge. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
